revised_title: Influence of Surface Topography on Oriented Chemical Overgrowths
tldr: The authors studied the growth of thin halide tarnish layers on silver crystals and how the orientation of the halide depends on the surface topography of the substrate. They used electron-diffraction patterns to analyze the contact planes between silver and halide for various orientations. The results showed that the orientation of the halide on specific crystal facets was independent of the position of those facets with respect to the macroscopic surface, and that surface irregularities, such as steps or cracks, played a role in the growth process.
